questions.text:
An obese  52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 8 hours. Two months ago, he noticed a mass on the right side of his neck and was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 27 years. He drinks two pints of rum daily. He appears ill. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Examination shows a 9-cm, tender, firm subglottic mass on the right side of the neck. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. His breathing is labored and he has audible inspiratory stridor but is able to answer questions. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.36


PCO2
45 mm Hg


PO2

74 mm Hg


HCO3-

25 mEq/L


He has no advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tracheal stent may be used to maintain tracheal patency following surgical resection of this patient's laryngeal cancer. Tracheal stents do not provide a controlled airway and are not used to treat acute respiratory distress.

B) CORRECT:

Tracheostomy is indicated in patients who will require long-term mechanical ventilation and/or in patients with upper airway obstruction causing respiratory distress. This patient will likely need long-term airway management while his laryngeal cancer is managed. Therefore, (percutaneous or open) tracheostomy is the preferred intervention because it will provide an airway that bypasses the tumor and can be used for long-term mechanical ventilation. Although endotracheal intubation would correct this patient's acute respiratory distress, it is not appropriate for long-term airway management (i.e., > 3 weeks), because of the associated risk of complications (e.g., tracheal stenosis, subglottic mass). If this patient were endotracheally intubated, he would eventually need a tracheostomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine is used for acute airway compromise due to anaphylaxis. This patient has not been exposed to a trigger for anaphylaxis (e.g., medication, food allergy, insect bite), however, and he lacks other symptoms of anaphylaxis (e.g., urticaria, itching, angioedema).

D) INCORRECT:

Comfort care measures may be appropriate later on in the management of this patient's cancer, if further care is deemed futile or he requests palliative care. However, this patient presents with acute respiratory distress and has no advanced directive, so treatment is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Cricothyroidotomy is indicated in patients who require emergency temporary airway management and cannot be intubated (e.g., contraindication or failure of endotracheal intubation). While this patient requires urgent airway management, he is conscious, responsive, and hemodynamically stable. Furthermore, he will likely need long-term (> 3 weeks) mechanical ventilation given the chronic nature of his airway obstruction and cricothyroidotomy is not indicated for long-term mechanical ventilation. Finally, because this patient's laryngeal mass is in the subglottic region (i.e., the area where an endotracheal tube would be inserted in a cricothyroidotomy), a cricothyroidotomy is contraindicated.
questions.hint: This patient has untreated laryngeal carcinoma and presents with respiratory distress with stridor and respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of hoarseness of voice and a chronic cough for the past 2 months. He has a history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 60 mL of whiskey every other day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy. Laryngoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous left posterior larynx; there is an exophytic mass arising from the left posterior true vocal cord. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukoplakia is a hyperkeratosis of the epithelium and mucous membranes of the oral cavity. It can present with hoarseness if it involves the larynx, and tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption are important risk factors. However, leukoplakia of the vocal cords manifests with persistent white plaques that cannot be scraped off on laryngoscopy, which is not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal papillomatosis is a benign tumor of the laryngeal epithelium that manifests with hoarseness and an exophytic lesion on the vocal cord on laryngoscopy. However, laryngeal papillomatosis is more common in children and young adults and is caused by HPV infection (HPV type 6 and 11). Moreover, a biopsy of the lesion shows hyperplastic stratified squamous epithelium with a central fibrovascular core, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

Laryngoscopy showing laryngeal papillomas, appearing as multiple raspberry-like swellings on vocal cords.

C) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal adenocarcinoma is very rare and is only seen in 1–2% of cases of laryngeal carcinoma. The photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen of the lesion does not show malignant adenomatous changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal amyloidosis is a localized form of amyloidosis, which can manifest with hoarseness, cough, and rarely lymphadenopathy. However, laryngoscopy typically shows a firm orange-yellow to gray epithelial nodule and a biopsy of the lesion shows an extracellular deposition and aggregation of amyloid, neither of which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is the most common type of laryngeal carcinoma and is usually located on the glottis or vocal cords. Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx is most common in men 40–70 years of age. Affected individuals typically present with chronic hoarseness or change in voice and cervical lymphadenopathy, as seen here. Other possible clinical signs are dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Laryngoscopy provides direct visualization of the lesion and typically reveals an irregular, nodular, or ulcerative lesion. Biopsy shows moderately differentiated clusters of squamous cells with lymphovascular invasion.

F) INCORRECT:

A vocal cord polyp is a benign lesion of the vocal cords. It can present with hoarseness, it is usually unilateral, and it is commonly associated with chronic irritation due to voice overuse (e.g., teachers, professional singers), smoking, or GERD. However, a vocal cord polyp is typically found in the middle to anterior one-third of the vocal fold (i.e., anterior larynx), unlike what is seen here. Moreover, this patient's unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy is not consistent with a polyp of the vocal cord.
questions.hint: Smoking and alcohol consumption are the most important risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the ED with a 2-day history of increasing difficulty swallowing solids and mild shortness of breath when speaking. He reports that his voice has been hoarse for the past six weeks, which he attributed to a lingering cold. He denies pain, fever, or cough. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and drinks alcohol daily. Physical examination reveals a breathy, weak voice and mild inspiratory stridor without oral lesions or neck tenderness. There is subtle fullness over the left side of the neck but no palpable lymphadenopathy or masses. Cranial nerves are intact. Vital signs are BP, 136/78 mm Hg; P, 88; R, 20; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); SpO₂, 96% on room air. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy secondary to a left apical (Pancoast) lung tumor
Metastatic lung carcinoma with brainstem lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pancoast tumor may cause recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy with hoarseness, but it typically presents with shoulder pain, arm paresthesias, or Horner syndrome due to brachial plexus and sympathetic chain involvement. The patient’s new dysphagia and stridor suggest direct laryngeal involvement rather than isolated nerve injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid carcinoma can cause dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness through extrinsic tracheal or recurrent laryngeal nerve compression, but it usually presents with a firm, palpable anterior neck mass. The lesion here is not palpable and the hoarseness preceded swallowing difficulty, favoring intrinsic laryngeal pathology.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Progressive hoarseness with recent dysphagia and mild stridor in a long-term smoker is classic for laryngeal carcinoma. Tumor involvement of the glottic or supraglottic region leads to chronic voice change and new airway or swallowing symptoms as the mass enlarges. In the ED, evaluation should include airway assessment and monitoring for impending obstruction. Urgent referral to otolaryngology for flexible nasolaryngoscopy and biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis and staging.

D) INCORRECT:

Metastatic spread from lung carcinoma can cause hoarseness and dysphagia through involvement of the vagus or glossopharyngeal nerves at the brainstem. However, this typically presents with additional focal neurologic deficits such as limb weakness, facial asymmetry, or ataxia. The gradual, isolated progression of hoarseness to dysphagia and stridor without other neurologic findings is more consistent with a primary laryngeal malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal carcinoma may cause progressive dysphagia and weight loss but typically begins with difficulty swallowing solids that progresses to liquids, without early hoarseness. The chronic voice change preceding dysphagia suggests a laryngeal rather than esophageal primary lesion.
